questions.question: The taxation of Social Security benefits is based on:

options.B: Provisional income including half of benefits

questions.explanation: Social Security taxability depends on provisional income (AGI + tax-exempt interest + 50% of benefits). Up to 50% is taxable if provisional income exceeds the first threshold; up to 85% is taxable above the second threshold.
questions.tip: Provisional income = AGI + tax-exempt interest + 50% of SS benefits. Determines how much of SS is taxable.

questions.question: Valid consideration requires:

options.B: A bargained-for exchange of legal value

questions.explanation: Consideration requires a bargained-for exchange where each party provides something of legal value (benefit to promisor or detriment to promisee). It doesn't require equal value—courts don't assess adequacy of consideration.
questions.tip: Consideration: bargained-for exchange + legal value. Courts don't evaluate adequacy (fairness).

questions.question: After a 2-for-1 stock split, the shareholder's per-share basis:

options.B: Is halved

questions.explanation: In a stock split, total basis remains the same but is divided among the new number of shares. In a 2-for-1 split, the shareholder has twice as many shares, so per-share basis is halved. No gain or loss is recognized.
questions.tip: Stock split: total basis unchanged, per-share basis adjusted. Stock dividend: similar treatment.

questions.question: A C corporation's capital losses can offset:

options.B: Only capital gains

questions.explanation: Corporate capital losses can only offset capital gains—they cannot offset ordinary income at all. Excess capital losses carry back 3 years and forward 5 years. This differs from individuals who can deduct $3,000 against ordinary income.
questions.tip: Corp capital losses: only offset capital gains. Carryback 3 years, forward 5 years. No $3,000 ordinary offset.

questions.question: The penalty for failure to make timely employment tax deposits ranges from:
questions.explanation: Failure to deposit penalties are tiered: 2% for 1-5 days late, 5% for 6-15 days late, 10% for 16+ days late, and 15% if not paid within 10 days of first IRS notice. Intentional failure can result in higher penalties.
questions.tip: Deposit penalties: 2% → 5% → 10% → 15% based on lateness. Use EFTPS for proper deposits.

questions.question: A Preparer Tax Identification Number (PTIN) is required for:

options.B: Anyone who prepares or assists in preparing federal tax returns for compensation

questions.explanation: Anyone who prepares or substantially assists in preparing any federal tax return for compensation must obtain a PTIN and include it on returns they prepare. PTINs must be renewed annually. This includes employed preparers, not just practice owners.
questions.tip: PTIN: required for any compensated preparer. Must renew annually. Include on all returns prepared.

questions.question: For divorce agreements executed before 2019, alimony paid is:

options.B: Deductible by the payer as an above-the-line deduction

questions.explanation: For pre-2019 divorce agreements, alimony is deductible by the payer (above-the-line) and taxable to the recipient. Post-2018 agreements eliminate this treatment—alimony is neither deductible nor taxable. Pre-2019 agreements can elect new treatment.
questions.tip: Alimony: pre-2019 = deductible/taxable. Post-2018 = no deduction/no income. Old agreements can elect new rules.

questions.question: A principal's duties to an agent include:

options.B: Compensation, reimbursement, and cooperation

questions.explanation: Principal's duties include: compensation (if agreed), reimbursement for authorized expenses, indemnification for losses from authorized acts, and cooperation (not interfering with agent's performance). The agent owes fiduciary duties to the principal.
questions.tip: Principal's duties: pay, reimburse, indemnify, cooperate. Agent's duties: loyalty, obedience, care.

questions.question: When an S corporation has both income and distributions in the same year, shareholder basis is:

options.B: Increased by income first, then reduced by distributions
options.C: Calculated at year-end using net amounts only
options.D: Not affected until the following year

questions.explanation: S corporation basis adjustments follow this order: (1) increase for income (including tax-exempt), (2) decrease for distributions (not below zero), (3) decrease for nondeductible expenses, (4) decrease for deductions and losses. This ordering maximizes tax-free distributions.
questions.tip: Basis order: + income, - distributions, - nondeductible expenses, - losses. Sequence matters!

questions.question: In a deferred like-kind exchange, a qualified intermediary is used to:

options.B: Hold the exchange proceeds to avoid taxpayer's actual or constructive receipt

questions.explanation: A qualified intermediary (QI) facilitates the exchange by holding sale proceeds and using them to acquire replacement property. Using a QI prevents actual or constructive receipt of cash, which would disqualify the exchange. The QI cannot be related to the taxpayer.
questions.tip: QI: holds funds, facilitates exchange. Avoids constructive receipt. Cannot be related party.

questions.question: The means test for Chapter 7 bankruptcy eligibility:

options.B: Compares debtor's income to state median income to determine abuse
options.D: Is performed by the debtor's attorney only

questions.explanation: The means test determines if Chapter 7 would be an abuse for above-median-income debtors. If current monthly income exceeds the state median, a complex calculation determines if sufficient disposable income exists for a Chapter 13 repayment plan instead.
questions.tip: Means test: above median income → presumption of abuse → may be forced to Chapter 13.

questions.question: A partner's recognized gain from a current cash distribution equals:

options.B: The excess of cash received over the partner's outside basis

questions.explanation: In a current (non-liquidating) distribution, gain is recognized only if cash received exceeds the partner's outside basis. Loss is never recognized in current distributions. Property distributions generally don't trigger gain.
questions.tip: Current distribution: gain only if cash > basis. No loss. Property = no gain (basis substituted).

questions.question: The residential clean energy credit for qualified solar installations is:

options.B: 30% of the cost with no annual limit

questions.explanation: The residential clean energy credit is 30% of costs for qualified solar, wind, geothermal, and battery storage installations through 2032. There's no annual limit or lifetime cap. The credit is nonrefundable but can be carried forward.
questions.tip: Solar/clean energy: 30% credit (through 2032). No cap. Nonrefundable with carryforward.

questions.question: For post-2020 NOLs, the deduction is limited to:

options.B: 80% of taxable income

questions.explanation: Post-2020 NOLs can offset only 80% of taxable income (computed without the NOL deduction). They cannot be carried back (except farming losses) but carry forward indefinitely. Pre-2018 NOLs followed different rules (2-year carryback, 20-year carryforward, 100% deduction).
questions.tip: Post-2020 NOL: 80% limit, no carryback (except farms), indefinite carryforward.

questions.question: The IRS must accept an installment agreement request if the tax owed is:

options.B: $50,000 or less, and the taxpayer agrees to pay within 72 months
options.C: Any amount if hardship is demonstrated

questions.explanation: The IRS must accept (guaranteed installment agreement) requests when tax owed is $50,000 or less and the taxpayer agrees to full payment within 72 months or the collection statute, whichever is shorter. The taxpayer must be in filing compliance.
questions.tip: Guaranteed IA: ≤$50K, pay in 72 months, in compliance. Streamlined IA has different thresholds.

questions.question: The Section 4(a)(2) private placement exemption applies to:

options.B: Transactions not involving a public offering

questions.explanation: Section 4(a)(2) exempts transactions not involving a public offering (private placements). Factors include number/sophistication of offerees, manner of offering (no advertising), and investor access to information. Regulation D provides safe harbors for this exemption.
questions.tip: 4(a)(2): private placement. Reg D provides safe harbors (Rules 504, 505, 506). No general solicitation for most.

questions.question: Property in a decedent's estate is generally valued at:

options.B: Fair market value on the date of death or alternate valuation date
options.D: Assessed value for property tax purposes

questions.explanation: Estate assets are valued at FMV on the date of death. The executor may elect the alternate valuation date (6 months later or earlier disposition date) if it reduces both the gross estate and estate tax liability. This valuation also becomes the heir's stepped-up basis.
questions.tip: DOD valuation: date of death or 6-month alternate. Alternate only if reduces both estate and tax.

questions.question: The FUTA wage base for 2024 is:

options.B: $10,000 per employee

questions.explanation: FUTA applies to the first $7,000 of each employee's wages. The full FUTA rate is 6.0%, but a 5.4% credit is available if state unemployment taxes are paid timely, resulting in an effective rate of 0.6%. This wage base has remained $7,000 since 1983.
questions.tip: FUTA: $7,000 wage base. 6% - 5.4% credit = 0.6% effective rate. Employer-only tax.

questions.question: Under Circular 230 best practices, a practitioner should:

options.A: Always provide the most aggressive tax position
options.B: Communicate clearly with the client and ensure they understand tax return positions

questions.explanation: Best practices include: communicating clearly about engagement terms, establishing facts and evaluating information, advising clients of correct tax return positions and consequences of positions taken, and acting fairly and with integrity.
questions.tip: Best practices: clear communication, establish facts, advise on positions, act with integrity.

questions.question: Distributions from a Section 529 education savings plan are tax-free if used for:

options.B: Qualified higher education expenses including tuition, fees, books, and room/board
options.D: Education expenses only in the contributor's state

questions.explanation: 529 distributions are tax-free for qualified higher education expenses: tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and room/board (for at least half-time students). Up to $10,000/year can also be used for K-12 tuition. Student loan payments up to $10,000 lifetime also qualify.
questions.tip: 529: tax-free for QHEE. Room/board OK if half-time. K-12 tuition OK ($10K/yr). Student loans ($10K lifetime).

questions.question: An intended beneficiary of a contract can enforce the contract when:

options.A: They learn of the contract's existence
options.B: Their rights have vested through assent, reliance, or suit

questions.explanation: An intended (not incidental) beneficiary can enforce the contract after their rights vest. Rights vest when the beneficiary: (1) assents to the promise, (2) materially relies on it, or (3) brings suit. Before vesting, the parties can modify or rescind.
questions.tip: Intended beneficiary: can enforce. Rights vest on assent, reliance, or suit. Incidental beneficiary: no rights.

questions.question: A partnership's required tax year is generally:

options.A: Any 12-month period elected by the partners
options.B: The tax year of partners owning a majority interest, or principal partners, or least aggregate deferral
options.C: The calendar year in all cases
options.D: The fiscal year of the managing partner

questions.explanation: Partnership tax year is determined by: (1) majority interest tax year (partners owning >50%), (2) if none, principal partners' tax year (partners with ≥5%), (3) if none, least aggregate deferral year. Section 444 allows fiscal year election with required payments.
questions.tip: Partnership year: majority interest → principal partners → least aggregate deferral. Prevents income deferral abuse.

questions.question: For assets placed in service in 2024, bonus depreciation is:

options.B: 60% of the cost, phasing down from 100% in 2022

questions.explanation: 100% bonus depreciation applied through 2022. It phases down: 80% in 2023, 60% in 2024, 40% in 2025, 20% in 2026, then expires. Bonus depreciation applies to new property with recovery periods of 20 years or less, and used property (with acquisition requirements).

questions.question: A surety can assert all defenses of the principal debtor EXCEPT:

options.A: Fraud in the inducement by the creditor
options.B: Bankruptcy of the principal debtor
options.C: Statute of limitations on the principal debt

questions.explanation: Sureties can assert most defenses available to the principal debtor (payment, fraud, statute of limitations, illegality). However, the debtor's personal defenses (bankruptcy, incapacity, death) cannot be asserted by the surety. The surety remains liable despite debtor's bankruptcy.
questions.tip: Surety can use debtor's contract defenses. Cannot use: debtor's bankruptcy, incapacity, death (personal defenses).

questions.question: A Type B reorganization (stock-for-stock) requires:

options.A: Boot of up to 20% of consideration
options.B: Solely voting stock as consideration for control of target

questions.explanation: Type B requires acquiring control (80%) using solely voting stock of the acquirer. No boot (cash or other property) is permitted. If any boot is paid, the entire transaction is taxable. This is the strictest reorganization regarding boot.
questions.tip: Type B: voting stock ONLY (no boot at all). Must get 80% control. Very strict requirements.

questions.question: The minimum tax credit (MTC) can be used in future years to offset:

options.B: Regular tax to the extent it exceeds tentative minimum tax

questions.explanation: The MTC is generated when AMT is paid on deferral items (like ISO exercises) that will reverse. In future years, the MTC can reduce regular tax liability to the extent regular tax exceeds tentative minimum tax. It prevents permanent double taxation of timing differences.
questions.tip: MTC: from deferral items (not exclusion items). Credits regular tax down to TMT. Carries forward indefinitely.

questions.question: The work product doctrine protects:

options.A: All documents prepared by an accountant
options.B: Materials prepared in anticipation of litigation
options.C: Tax returns filed with the IRS

questions.explanation: Work product doctrine protects documents and tangible things prepared in anticipation of litigation. It's broader than attorney-client privilege and can protect accountant work product. However, it can be overcome if the opposing party shows substantial need and inability to obtain equivalent information.
questions.tip: Work product: prepared for litigation. Can be overcome for substantial need. Mental impressions get stronger protection.

questions.question: A trust is a grantor trust if the grantor retains:

options.A: Only the right to receive income
options.B: Powers such as the ability to revoke, control beneficial enjoyment, or certain administrative powers

questions.explanation: Grantor trust status arises when the grantor retains: power to revoke, power to control beneficial enjoyment, certain administrative powers (borrow without security, substitute assets), power to distribute income to grantor/spouse, or reversionary interest over 5%.
questions.tip: Grantor trust: grantor retains too much control. Trust income taxed to grantor. Intentional grantor trusts = planning tool.

questions.question: When an agent contracts on behalf of an undisclosed principal:

options.B: The agent is personally liable to the third party, and the principal is also liable once disclosed
options.D: The third party must sue the agent only

questions.explanation: With an undisclosed principal, the agent is personally liable because the third party believed they were contracting with the agent. Once the principal is disclosed, the third party can elect to hold either the agent or principal liable (but not both for the same damages).
questions.tip: Undisclosed principal: agent liable (appeared to be the contracting party). Third party can elect agent or principal once known.

questions.question: Qualified nonrecourse financing in a real estate partnership is allocated:

options.B: To partners based on their profit-sharing ratios (generally)
options.C: To the partner with the largest capital account
options.D: Not included in any partner's basis

questions.explanation: Qualified nonrecourse financing (real estate secured debt from qualified lenders) is allocated to partners based on their profit-sharing ratios, allowing limited partners to include this debt in basis for at-risk purposes. This is an exception to the general rule that nonrecourse debt doesn't create at-risk basis.
questions.tip: Qualified nonrecourse real estate debt: at-risk for all partners. Allocated by profit ratios. Exception to at-risk rules.

questions.question: For incentive stock options (ISOs), the bargain element at exercise:

options.B: Is not regular income but is an AMT adjustment

questions.explanation: ISO exercise creates no regular tax income, but the bargain element (FMV minus exercise price) is an AMT adjustment. If qualifying holding periods are met (2 years from grant, 1 year from exercise), gain at sale is long-term capital gain. Disqualifying disposition results in ordinary income.
questions.tip: ISO: no regular income at exercise, but AMT adjustment. LTCG if holding periods met. NQSO: ordinary income at exercise.

questions.question: A correspondence audit involves:

options.A: An IRS agent visiting the taxpayer's home
options.B: Written requests for documentation to verify specific items
options.C: A full review of all records at an IRS office

questions.explanation: Correspondence audits are conducted by mail—the IRS requests specific documentation to verify items on the return. They're typically for simple issues (W-2 discrepancies, charitable deductions). Office audits are at IRS offices; field audits are at taxpayer's location for complex cases.
questions.tip: Audit types: correspondence (mail), office (IRS office), field (taxpayer location). Complexity increases with each type.

questions.question: When a buyer obtains property in a Section 267 related-party loss sale and later sells at a gain:

options.A: The buyer recognizes the full gain
options.B: The buyer can offset the gain by the disallowed loss (but not create a loss)
options.C: The disallowed loss is lost forever
options.D: The buyer has no gain recognition

questions.explanation: When property from a Section 267 loss sale is resold, the buyer can offset their gain by the seller's previously disallowed loss. However, the disallowed loss cannot create or increase a loss—it only reduces gain. Any unused portion of the disallowed loss disappears.
questions.tip: Section 267 disallowed loss: buyer uses to offset gain only. Can't create loss. Unused portion = gone.

questions.question: A shareholder derivative action allows shareholders to:

options.B: Sue on behalf of the corporation for harm done to the corporation

questions.explanation: Derivative actions are suits brought by shareholders on behalf of the corporation when directors fail to act on corporate claims. Recovery goes to the corporation, not the suing shareholder. Shareholders must first demand board action (unless futile) and show contemporaneous ownership.
questions.tip: Derivative suit: shareholder sues for corporation's benefit. Recovery to corp. Demand required (unless futile).

questions.question: An S election is involuntarily terminated when:

options.B: An ineligible shareholder acquires stock or eligibility requirements are otherwise violated

questions.explanation: S election terminates when eligibility requirements are violated: ineligible shareholder (corporation, partnership, NRA) acquires stock, more than 100 shareholders, second class of stock created, or passive income rule violation (for corps with E&P). Termination can be prospective or retroactive.
questions.tip: S termination events: ineligible shareholder, >100 shareholders, 2nd class of stock, passive income violation.
